articles.title: What is Information Technology?
articles.author: Olivia Brown
articles.content:
Information Technology (IT) is the backbone of the modern digital world, encompassing the use of computers, networks, software, and systems to store, process, transmit, and secure data. IT is not just about fixing computers; it's a vast field that powers everything from global financial systems and healthcare databases to personal smartphones and smart home devices. At its core, IT solves problems and improves efficiency through technology.

The field of IT can be divided into several key areas:
• Computer Hardware: The physical components like processors (CPUs), memory (RAM), storage drives (HDDs/SSDs), and peripherals (keyboards, printers).
• Software: Programs and operating systems (like Windows, macOS, or Linux) that enable hardware to perform tasks.
• Networking: The infrastructure that connects devices, allowing communication and data sharing (e.g., LANs, WANs, the internet).
• Data Management: Storing, organizing, and retrieving information using databases and cloud systems.
• Cybersecurity: Protecting systems and data from digital threats like hackers and malware.

IT professionals work in diverse roles, from system administrators who maintain networks to software developers who create applications. The field is constantly evolving, with emerging areas like artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain, and the Internet of Things (IoT) creating new opportunities.

articles.title: Basics of Computer Hardware and Software
articles.author: Alex Rivera
articles.content:
A computer system is made up of two main elements: hardware and software. Understanding both is important for anyone interested in technology.

Computer hardware refers to the physical parts of a computer system. This includes:
• Central Processing Unit (CPU) – the brain of the computer that processes instructions.
• Random Access Memory (RAM) – temporary memory used to run programs quickly.
• Hard Drive (HDD) or Solid-State Drive (SSD) – where files and programs are stored.
• Motherboard – the main circuit board connecting all components.
• Input Devices – like keyboards, mice, and scanners.
• Output Devices – like monitors, printers, and speakers.

Software, on the other hand, is a set of instructions that tells the hardware what to do. Software can be divided into two types:
• System software – like operating systems (Windows, macOS, Linux) that manage hardware and allow other programs to run.
• Application software – like Microsoft Word, web browsers, or games that let users perform specific tasks.

Without software, hardware is useless. And without hardware, software has nothing to run on. Both work together to make computers useful tools in business, education, and personal life.

articles.title: Understanding Operating Systems
articles.author: Alex Rivera
articles.content:
An Operating System (OS) is essential software that acts as a bridge between the user, applications, and the computer hardware. It controls the system’s memory, processes, devices, and software.

Some of the most common operating systems include:
• Microsoft Windows – widely used in homes and offices.
• macOS – used on Apple’s desktop and laptop computers.
• Linux – popular in servers and tech environments.
• Android and iOS – used in mobile phones and tablets.

The OS performs several important functions:
• Manages hardware resources, like the CPU, memory, and storage.
• Provides a user interface, such as a desktop or command line.
• Handles system security, including user permissions and virus protection.
• Manages files, allowing users to create, delete, and organize data.
• Runs applications, ensuring software can access needed resources.

Without an operating system, you would not be able to use your computer. It plays a central role in everything from browsing the internet to playing music or writing a report.
